definitions.definition: the ability to control people or things
definitions.sensetop: power to do somethingpower over somebody/somethingin your power

examples.text: He **has the power** to make things very unpleasant for us.
Religion is **losing its power** to shape our behaviour.
The aim is to **give** people more **power** over their own lives.
The government **wields** enormous **power** over the economy.
She had him completely in her power *(= was able to do what she liked with him)*.
In those days the king **exercised** real **political power**.
She sits on the board but has no executive power.
The company was too small to hold two such power-hungry men.
They held us in their power.
She was now in a position of power and influence.

power + verb: be concentrated in (the hands of somebody/​something)
phrases: abuse of power
the balance of power
a bid for power

definitions.definition: political control of a country or an area

examples.text: Hitler **seized power** in Germany in 1933.
The following year he **took power** in a military coup.
Labour won two elections in 1974, but **lost power** in 1979.
The present regime has been in power for two years.
The party **came to power** at the last election.
They are hoping to return to power.
a **power struggle** between rival factions within the party
The Crown prince assumed power in his father's place.
People say that the First Lady is the power behind the throne.
The emperor held no real power.
The real legislative power still rests with the lower chamber.
The war brought about a shift in the balance of power.
They fell from power in 1992.
They held power for 18 years.
the transfer of power from a military to a civilian government
He seized power in a military coup.
The Emperor had absolute power over all his subjects.

power + verb: be concentrated in (the hands of somebody/​something)
phrases: abuse of power
the balance of power
a bid for power

definitions.definition: energy that can be collected and used to operate a machine, to make electricity, etc.

examples.text: **nuclear/wind/solar power**
engine power
wave power
They used these streams to **generate power** for the mill.
Solar **power generation** is greatly affected by cloud cover.
The generator supplies power for lighting,
The plane was still climbing at full power.
The transmitter is operating on reduced power.
This wheel provides the power to the cutting machine.
Wind power is used to drive the machinery.
The cost of solar power is falling all the time.

phrases: a source of power

definitions.definition: the public supply of electricity

examples.text: They've switched off the power.
She was in the elevator when the power went off.
The country's **power supply** is stretched to the limit.
the national **power grid**
a **power failure**

phrases: a source of power

definitions.definition: the quality of having great power or force, or of being very effective

examples.text: The ship was helpless against the power of the storm.
They were impressed by the power of her arguments.
Researchers are **harnessing the power** of computer modelling to find solutions to these challenges.
It was a performance of great power.
He wants to change the world through the power of prayer.
the destructive power of a hurricane
the healing power of sleep
the raw power of their music

definitions.definition: physical strength used in action; physical strength that somebody possesses and might use

examples.text: She hit the ball with as much power as she could.
the sheer physical power of the man

definitions.definition: the ability or opportunity to do something

examples.text: I will **do everything in my power** to help you.
It is not within my power *(= I am unable)* to help you.
He did everything in his power to find us somewhere to live.
a task still beyond any computer's power

phrases: at the height of your powers
at the peak of your powers
at the zenith of your powers

definitions.definition: a particular ability of the body or mind

examples.text: Spiderman **uses his powers** to fight crime.
She had lost the power of speech.
The drug may affect your powers of concentration.
He had to use all his powers of persuasion.
a tribute to his powers as a teacher
her powers of observation
He felt his mental powers failing.
They believe she has supernatural powers.

phrases: at the height of your powers
at the peak of your powers
at the zenith of your powers

definitions.definition: all the abilities of a person’s body or mind

examples.text: At 26, he is **at the height of his powers** and ranked fourth in the world.

phrases: at the height of your powers
at the peak of your powers
at the zenith of your powers

definitions.definition: the right or authority of a person or group to do something
definitions.sensetop: power to do somethingpower of something

examples.text: The powers of the police must be clearly defined.
The court can only **exercise powers** granted to it by statute.
City rulers **abused their power** by using public funds for private purposes.
This sort of **abuse of power** is unacceptable.
The Secretary of State has the power to approve the proposals.
The president has the power of veto over all new legislation.
Police in riot gear used their powers under the Public Order Act to move on 300 protesters.
The court has no power to order a psychiatric examination of the child's parents.
The government has limited legal powers over television.
The new law delegates many of these powers to school governors.
certain powers that were granted to the government
Some states delegate police power to municipalities.

power + verb: be concentrated in (the hands of somebody/​something)
phrases: abuse of power
the balance of power
a bid for power

definitions.definition: a country with a lot of influence in world affairs, or with great military strength

examples.text: He transformed a backward country into a **world power**.
**major** European **powers** such as France and Germany
Türkiye is growing as an **economic power**.
The influence of the former colonial power is still very much in evidence.

definitions.definition: strength or influence in a particular area of activity

examples.text: These companies have enormous **economic power**.
the exercise of **military power**
air/sea power *(= military strength in the air/at sea)*
The **purchasing power** of today's youth is higher than ever.
Several years ago, computer **processing power** was considerably less than it is now.
The country's dominance was assured by its technological and military power.

phrases: at the height of your powers
at the peak of your powers
at the zenith of your powers

definitions.definition: the influence of a particular thing or group within society

examples.text: Hollywood **star power**
Parent power has helped save the school from closure.
the power of the media
Values are distorted by the power of advertising.

phrases: at the height of your powers
at the peak of your powers
at the zenith of your powers

definitions.definition: the number of times that an amount is to be multiplied by itself

examples.text: 4 to the power of 3 is 43 (= 4 × 4 × 4 = 64).

definitions.definition: the amount by which a lens can make objects appear larger

examples.text: the power of a microscope/telescope

definitions.definition: a good or evil spirit that controls the lives of others

examples.text: the powers of darkness *(= the forces of evil)*
She believed in the existence of a benevolent power.
belief in a higher power

power + verb: be concentrated in (the hands of somebody/​something)
phrases: abuse of power
the balance of power
a bid for power

definitions.definition: the higher levels of government, where important decisions are made

examples.text: She had considerable influence in the corridors of power.

definitions.definition: to be very good for somebody’s physical or mental health

examples.text: A break would do us all a power of good.

definitions.definition: used to encourage somebody or express support for their actions
the person who really controls an organization, a country, etc. in contrast to the person who is legally in charge

examples.text: His assistant was thought to be the real power behind the throne.

definitions.definition: the people who control an organization, a country, etc.

examples.text: The powers that be are still trying to decide what should be done.

definitions.definition: to win an election by a large number of votes; to make somebody win an election with a large number of votes

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French poeir, from an alteration of Latin posse ‘be able’.
